abstract.p: Metropolitan Museum of Art to open exhibition of works that explore history of art in New York City, 1825-1861, period when city began to see itself as world cultural center; Carnegie Hall plans celebration of 80th birthday of Isaac Stern, violinist and its president, including museum retrospective of his life and concert; Chicago to open Museum Week, with 22 museums featuring current and permanent attractions under tented canopy and 27 participating museums offering 2-for-1 admissions; photos (M)

block.p: Onward, Upward A time machine waiting to transport today's New Yorkers back to the city as it was in the second quarter of the 19th century opens for business tomorrow. That is when the Metropolitan Museum of Art opens an exhibition of more than 300 works that explore the history of art during that fertile period when New York City began to see itself as a world center of culture. Included in the exhibition, ''Art and the Empire City: New York, 1825-1861,'' are paintings and sculpture, city plans and architecture, photography, prints, decorative arts and fashion. The exhibition continues through Jan. 7. Information: (212) 535-7710.

A Birthday Tribute New York without Carnegie Hall may seem unthinkable, but once upon a time this grand auditorium had to be saved from the wrecker's ball. And the man who led the good fight was the violinist Isaac Stern. The year was 1960, and ever since Mr. Stern has been the president of Carnegie Hall. On July 21 Mr. Stern turned 80, and now Carnegie Hall is about to do something for him. It is going to celebrate his birthday in a big way, with not one but two days of observances. ''Isaac Stern at 80: A Carnegie Hall Celebration'' begins at 11 a.m. Saturday, a day devoted to a museum retrospective of his life, featuring material from his personal archives, and to screenings of films about him. Sunday is a day of performances, beginning at 1 p.m. It concludes at 7:30 p.m., when the Symphony Orchestra of the Curtis Institute of Music and distinguished friends and colleagues of Mr. Stern present a birthday concert. Among those scheduled to appear are Emanuel Ax, Yefim Bronfman, Sarah Chang, Glenn Dicterow, Midori, Yo-Yo Ma, Arnold Steinhardt and Pinchas Zukerman. Information: (212) 247-7800.

Urban Riches Under a tented canopy on Daley Plaza, Chicago will usher in Museum Week beginning at 8 a.m. today, when 22 museums, including the Field Museum and the Museum of Contemporary Art, show off current and permanent attractions. During the weeklong celebration of the city's museums and cultural institutions, a total of 27 participating museums feature 2-for-1 admissions and attractions like the works of William Merritt Chase at the Art Institute of Chicago and 20th-century avant-garde Russian art at the Chicago Cultural Center. Information: (312) 744-2400.
